InTheBox provides a local developers environment on a Macbook Pro containing kubernetes, kafka, elastic, prometheus and many more to enable the developer in developing and testing containerized applications.

After committing the created application OnePipeline comes in in building, scanning and deploying the application on Azure or in house ICHP container environment.

This is again a switch to a whole other area. I have stepped out of the Elastic environment, just like I've stepped out of other areas. Once you're the expert the fun is gone. MS Azure is a whole new area for me. Another great opportunity to learn new things and extend my knowledge and network.

projects.title: Design and Implement an active-active WB Channels C3 Elastic Application logging cluster
projects.description:
The current WbElastic implementation is implemented with a cold standby implementation as recommended by Elastic. We plan to implement an active-active implementation for reasons:
- One cold standby server costs the same as 1 server in each data centre.
- Use the already paid capacity within the recovery data centre.
- The distance between the data centres is limited to 50km.
- The Netherlands has an excellent non disruptive network implementation.

Requirements:
- The current cold standby implementation is and stays online during migration to active-active

projects.title: Poc and implementation in production to use Elastic with a Basic License behind WbSecurityProxy
projects.description:
Functionality within the Elastic Basic License has been extended with security. Everything is there with the exception of enterprise login. 

This proof of concept needs to proof that WbSecurityProxy can be used to authenticate the user and that his identity can be passed to Elastic.

The POC showed that WbSecurityProxy can authenticate the user with MFA. This user is logged into Elastic with a Basic Authorization header which contains the user and a fixed password. The authorized users with their roles mapping is inserted upfront. This setup saves license costs (Elastic or Search Guard) that can go over Euro 100k per year.

The proof of concept was implemented within 2 weeks.

projects.title: Automate RSA Web Threat Detection monitoring and maintenance procedures
projects.description:
To be honest I'm a lazy person, but I have lots of energy to automate tasks that are done in a routine way. I created a script that runs every 5 minutes on the RSA WTD processor that checks all items that had trouble in the past. So I check if we can login/logout, check the Linux files system space, ping all the machines within the configuration, check if all RSA WTD tasks are up and running, check if the Java Unlimited Policy has been removed (again), check all TCP/IP connections between the processor and the RSA WTD tap systems, check if Mitigator-0 is still running even when the schema is pushed without errors!, check for RSA WTD failed tasks and restart them automatically after 15 minutes (always works!), check if we have double traffic (1 of the 2 taps should be switched off). 

And when something fails (every now and then) I get a mail on my phone.

The RSA WTD tap systems contains a script that checks every minute if the processor is moved to the DR location or back. In that case the SilverTap needs to restarted, otherwise TCP/IP will keep trying to connect to the previous location, leading to no connection. This script also switches the taps (we have 2 taps in every data center) weekly and keeps one SilverTap switched off that should be off. RSA WTD switches SilverTap on after every push. So we have all taps within the configuration (for pushes) and we see them working regularly.

projects.title: Implement multi-application cyber fraud approach
projects.description:
The RSA Web Threat Detection implementation guards several applications. Ruling within RSA WTD was looking like if app1-country=="nl"​ or app2-country=="nl"​ or and so on. There is a lot of maintenance effort when other countries need to be added or new application are added to the RSA WTD solution.

I have implemented "global"​ variables in a way that @country will contain the value of whichever application comes by. Ruling is simplified like if @country=="nl". Maintenance is currently a simpler task.

projects.title: Design and Implement the WB Channels C3 Elastic Application logging cluster
projects.description:
Bank regulation does not allow engineers to log into the servers. And if we look into the future of cloud computing, there is no server to log in.
Therefore Wholesale Banking asked me to build a WbElastic environment to be the portal to application logging. This environment is build behind WbSecurityProxy which will authenticate the users with MFA before logging into WbElastic.

Together with the high skilled members of the WbSecurityProxy team we brought this solution into production within 8 months.

The environment is an Elastic stack which is secured with Search Guard. Wholesale banking Teams need to implement Elastic beats/Logstash within their solution. Their Logstash will encrypted (Ruby script supplied by us) all data and published this to a Kafka topic. WbElastic will read all topics, decrypts, stores this into the Teams indices and provides all Teams a view on their application logging.

Logstash will besides writing to the Elastic index, also write to gzipped file for backup purposes.

projects.title: Implement a Elastic Packetbeat -> Apache Kafka -> Apache Flink Web Fraud detection platform
projects.description:
There is a need for fraud detection on the http traffic between the customer (browser, tablet, mobile) and the web server. In this project 'm the technical lead of a very talented team. We build a platform where the (http) 'clicks' are forwarded to a Linux tap system. In there the http packets are assembled and forwarded to an Apache Kafka topic by Elastic Packetbeat. On the other side we've implemented an Apache Flink instance (stand alone in the initial setup). Detection logic has been implemented within this Flink instance with Scala programs. You can understand that this is a simplified representation of what actually is implemented.

Challenges for this project are: 
- Implement authentication/authorisation on the Apache Flink dashboard
- Encrypting the data on the Apache Kafka topic; 
- Building CDaaS pipelines for running the Scala logic within Flink
- Building CDaaS pipelines for maintaining the Apache Flink instance
- Get all monitoring in place
  - Application monitoring of critical files
  - Send application logging with filebeat to a central logging instance
  - Implement Auditbeat for software assurance

Users from the bank its internal network had access to all our Linux servers. The implemented Stepping Stone Linux machine is a way to limit the people attempting to login into the Linux servers. The project had the following steps:
- Define a private network area with the Cloud environment
- Define a Stepping Stone machine within the Cloud environment, including DR
- Arrange access from the internal network to the Stepping Stone machine
- Arrange access from the Stepping Stone machine to our Linux servers
- Define the users on the Stepping Stone machine that are allowed to login to the Linux servers

projects.title: Extend an Elastic single node cluster to a 4 node cluster for cyber fraud prevention
projects.description:
The initial implemented single Elastic node cluster is extended to a 4-node cluster (1 master, 3 workers) in 5 steps. The 4-node is not optimum, we're working on it! First step is moving the communication of the single node from localhost to $HOSTNAME, so the implementation of the cluster can be done without further disruption. Second step is to install the worker nodes and test the transport layer by adding them as coordinator nodes. Third step is adding them (restart) as worker nodes. At that moment Elastic will balance the indices over the 4 machines and for the first time we saw a green health. Step 4 is adding cluster routing allocation, excluding the master node. This will empty the to become master node. Step 3 and 4 took a whole day and production just went on without issues. The fifth step is to restart the to become master node with a true master node yml config.

We already had File- and Metricbeat implemented. Added to that is Heartbeat for monitoring the Elasticsearch instances and Kibana. Secondly we use Auditbeat for software assurance. The Auditbeat config file contains 8.5k directory entries (use find to define) of the Elastic stack (Elasticsearch, Kibana, Logstash and all Beats) software and configuration. On issues its clear which files have been changed or better there isn't changed anything. Remember you can use Auditbeat (for free) even if you do not have an Elastic stack. Just let Auditbeat write to an audit trail file or even better to Kafka to move the alerts to another platform.

profile_positions.description:
TurboHercules™ is the first commercial entity exclusively dedicated to Hercules, the well-known open source software implementation of the IBM mainframe architecture.

The Hercules open source emulator is a distinct software layer positioned between a mainframe operating system and a non-mainframe operating system (e.g. Linux, Windows, Solaris or MacOS).  It allows these non-mainframe operating systems to run mainframe applications on a variety of hardware platforms using AMD or Intel processors.  

Hercules is fully capable of running current versions of IBM’s modern 64-bit operating systems such as z/OS, z/VM, and z/VSE, as well as its older 31-bit and 24-bit operating systems.

Throughout its ten years of existence, Hercules has been positioned as a valuable contributor to the IBM mainframe ecosystem.  Above all, Hercules is a community of “IBM mainframers” who enthusiastically support the computing paradigm that has provided their livelihood.  Developers at TurboHercules are active participants in the open source community and are dedicated to contributing their improvements back to the Hercules project.
profile_positions.title: Co-founder

profile_positions.description:
In the end of 1999 I heard the existence of a mainframe emulator that would run within a PC environment. I expressed my disbelieve and two day later I received a plastic bag full of floppy disks. Three days later I saw a working concept. It was amazing.

After hearing my experience with the C language, the developpers (Jan Jaeger, Roger Bowler, Greg Smith and others) invited me to implement compression. I tried to understand the IBM manual, but found it for the functionality unusable. So, together with the help of Mario Bezzi's test programs and lots of hours reversed engeneering I finally had a working solution. The implementation has evolved and (performance) improved throughout the years.

Something similar happened for the crypto part. Implementing was a tough task, but it was the best opportunity in studying all down to earth cryptographic details.

Besides compression and crypto I have implemented many features like the Hercules Automatic Operator, coloured OS messages within the Hercules terminal, the UTF translate feature, a feature for capping the processors, many performance upgrades and many, many more.

I stopped developping in November 2012, but every now and then someone out there is asking to implement new features or repair bugs. Normally I can't say no!
